roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, in the first place I take it that the secretary of the man making the affidavit is speaking for the organization of which he is an officer, and that he has ascertained what its action and what its attitude and what its action is.
We have the doctrine that means (Inaudible) and commercial corporations, let alone the secretary of a church finding out that the political (Inaudible) or the members of the (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does he just get an order from the Board of Trustees or some other church?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I take it that would be --
After you pass that theory (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I take it that would be his justification --
(Inaudible) Now what do they -- to suggest (Inaudible) with reference to exemption, church organizations, setup the procedure where churches would take a vote in order to get that exemption?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.
The --
How does the secretary have power to do that, to get the exemption if he doesn't have the power to file this affidavit?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The statute merely provides that the exemption must be claimed by the claimant each year during the assessment season and prior to a certain date, and the affidavit claiming that exemption provided to him for his signature contains recital in the language of the affidavit that the claimant does not advocate the overthrow of the government by force, violence or other unlawful means.
Then the claimant would be the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The church.
The church?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The church, yes.
Would be the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The property owner.
Would be (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It would be the property owner, the church organization.
Precisely as it is with regard to an individual, if the individual claimant, whether he be a veteran or whoever else might claim --
The trouble is that a church body isn't precisely the same as an individual, that's the difference?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's the same difficulty that a corporation is not the same as a person and a normal --

Mr. Boller may I ask you about one other, what's the reference in the other half of the statement, "Nor advocate the support of a foreign government against the United States in event of hostilities."

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
(Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That I construe to mean advocating war support, war time support of an enemy of the United States.
Well at the time these were executed, were we at war with any foreign government?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This was in 1952, 1953, we were not --
These were between 1952 and 1953.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We were not at war no Your Honor.
Well then what purpose does this serve?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It was for the purpose of assuring against such advocacy.
The attitude and the --

I mean that the church doesn't get up now and say if ever we go to war with a foreign power, we advocate that we don't support or that we support the foreign government, whoever it might be against the United States?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That is -- that's the more difficult of the alternatives that the Constitution and statute provision carry --
It's pretty close, isn't it, in making a prophetic statement that churches won't be guilty of treason (Inaudible) or advocate the support of a foreign government against the United States.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Except that it's in the present tense.
Well I said this is a prophetic statement, that is undefined future.
These are facts will not be guilty of treason.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No it's in the present tense I think Your Honor.
Well --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That they do not now advocate the support of a foreign government.
I remember when we still at war with Japan (Inaudible) Hiroshima, weren't they?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I should think that was probably so, yes.
But --
That kind of an act be covered by this oath?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I wouldn't think so, I wouldn't think so.
I think the aid to individuals in distress, even of a foreign power at war with us --

How about the advocacy that we don't use the H-bomb on hostilities, those who are actually at war, would the church would advocate it that we not use the H-bomb, would that supporting a foreign power?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I shouldn't think so, no.

The question of policy, government policy and action, the question of the conduct of men in office, the possibility of criticism of officials in government for venal or corrupt conduct, those are matters that are fully open to question, to criticism, to --
Well, doesn't your answer Mr. Boller suggest the vagueness of the statute?
What is supportive of a foreign government, what is advocating the support of a foreign government?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: A foreign government is not something else.
It isn't the individuals, the stressed individuals who constitute its populous for one thing.
I may run over it somewhat by elimination.
It does not constitute the individuals.
It represents the agency.
It represents the government as its states.
It is with respect to government action.
It is not with respect to individual need, individual merit it maybe.
It is not with regard to disassociated individual conduct.

Mr. Boller are you in a position to state whether (Inaudible) a foreign government in the event of hostilities, that's so hypothetical and so (Inaudible) to the future, it is to unrelated to anything (Inaudible).
In other words I'm asking whether you're prepared to say that (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think probably I'm speculating merely, I haven't had the suggestion made before as Your Honor is putting it, that the claimant is signing part and is striking the balance.
I suppose if you (Inaudible) ruling of your Supreme Court, the statute to provide that (Inaudible), is that right?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think maybe so, whether it was divisible, whether the fact that one part failed would necessarily carry down the other is --
What did you tell the Court (Inaudible); what would you advise as you are the advisor for the government?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: As advisor to the County Assessor of Los Angeles County, we'd tell them to grant the exemption probably.
That would be your opinion on it.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Off hand, it's been rather an off hand opinion here, yes.
(Inaudible) Mr. Boller your constitution says that that's what the (Inaudible), statement has to --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I don't want to be led into conceding too much, I shouldn't do that should I? [Laughter]
Well, I just wonder whether -- perhaps your Board of Assessors might not feel no regard, I'm they have been advised that the constitution says otherwise.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But if this Court says that part of the constitution is out, then that would (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If the men down in Washington did that, why it would good enough for us that go along I'm sure. [Laughter]
Suppose the next church that came along and said we like this, they don't like this, this is the first part, we just came, now this first part we just (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Now the first part is clear, the first part is language that has been adjudicated.
There is not the uncertainty about that, that you gentlemen are suggesting as to the second.
You would let him off (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: As to that no surely not.
The answer to that can be easy and can be clear.
Have you got a surplus in your treasury, you're giving away a lot of money. [Laughter]

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The basis for this exemption, the basis for these two provisions of constitution and of statute, is not apprehension of overthrow of government, it is not peril to the government, it is not a matter of clear and present danger to the persistence and continuance of government.
It is instead danger of defeat of the purpose for which the exemption is granted.

The exemption is accorded as I suggested earlier as an aid to the general atmosphere in which a constitutional government exists, for its benefit in raising the standards of conduct and morality in private and public life, and the danger is of defeating that purpose which is sought to be accomplished by the granting of the exemption, its not a danger of overthrow of the government.
Mr. Wirin in his argument --
Well, would you strip all the language of it, it's to keep communists out of the churches.
No, it isn't Your Honor.
Or to get the church's support to keep communists out of the -- keep them out from their numbers.
No that's quite too narrow, that's quite to narrow Your Honor.
It's to maintain a high attitude and teaching, high position by the church in the community as an aid toward advancing morals and virtue and integrity and ideals in the populous.
And that, that --
From this provision?

And that the church or any other recipient of exemption benefit, who advocates these doctrines, is acting contrary to such an influence, is ceasing to meet the purpose for which the exemption is granted.
Is there any legislative discussion of this statute after the referendum?
There is -- no, there is discussion of it as indicating the purposes of the exemption in the opinion by the California court which is here under review --
So that their lawyers argue -- I was wondering whether there was anything in the legislative history that shows that it's directed towards communists or some other (Inaudible) in California.
The only thing that bears on that at all is the argument to the voters which is to be provided to you gentlemen and that --
Does that talk about communists?
Pardon me?
Does that talk about communists?
It does to an extent, yes.

It speaks of the benefiting communists and others of that sort, but the purpose of legislation as I was starting to say is indicated in the opinion of the Court, if I'm reading in the record at page 51.

It first indicates reading at the bottom of the page, it first indicates a very insignificant purpose to be accomplished, the interest of the state in protecting its revenue raising program from subversive exploitation has already been considered.
Then it goes on, there are additional interests with which the state is concerned and which it is attempting to promote by granting exemptions from taxation.
Included is the interest of the state in maintaining the loyalty of its people and thus safeguarding against its violent overthrow by internal or external forces.

This legitimate objective is sought to be accomplished by placing any favored economic position and thus to promote their wellbeing and sphere of the influence, those particular persons and groups of individuals who are capable of formulating policies relating to good morals and respect for the law.

It has been said that when church properties are exempted from taxation, it must be because apart from religious considerations, churches as regarded as institutions established to inculcate principles of sound morality leading citizens to a more ready obedience to the laws.
The same maybe said about as enjoying tax exemptions.

Tell me Mr. Boller, it all have sum up to this and also your answer to Mr. Justice Harlan, not that there is any present infiltration of these petitioner churches or any other, that the whole purpose of this thing is to keep the churches on their toes against being infiltrated by those who might turn them away from the things that the Court has said are the objectives they are there to serve, is that it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: To keep them away and turn them away from --
To keep them on their toes, to keep themselves cleansed on any possible infiltrators who might (Inaudible), is that it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Infiltration of communists would be one --
In other words, not that there are any there now, but just against the chance that some day some might come there, this would keep the churches on their toes.
Is that it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As I'm saying the issue in the case is not as to whether the particular church advocates or does not advocate it --
I appreciate that, that's what I'm assuming.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
That they don't advocate, none of these petitioners churches does and the only reason for attaching this --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We're not saying that none of them does, we're saying that is beside the point, we do not know.
We can assume that they do not.
At least we can assume that they will not on this record, is that right?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I don't think we need to make -- that we're entitled to make an assumption one way or the other because there is no basis in the record for the assumption.
It has not been alleged that they do not advocate.
The complaint does not allege that they do not advocate.
The complaint doesn't -- neither brings the church within the constitutional provision, it does not bring it within the constitutional provision by alleging that they do not advocate.
It affirmatively places it outside the statute --
Well on this record how do you want us to approach this, on the premise if they do advocate or in the premise they do not?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I want to approach it, disassociate it entirely from the question and without assumption one way or the other.
I think the petitioners are not entitled to say that they do not advocate, because they have not made that an issue in the case.
In consequence it was not considered in the trial court, it could not be, it was a question purely of law as has been indicated, question raised by the merits of the complaint.
Mr. Boller if the purpose of this is to keep the churches on their toes against certain things, what does that do to your doctrine of separation (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well that wasn't my phrase, keep them on their toes. [Laughter]
You may borrow it though Mr. Boller.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Its --
(Inaudible) I understood you to say that the purpose of the state was to require the churches to maintain high ideals and advocate high doctrine.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes, yes, that's part of the language.
The state wants to require the churches to maintain doctrines that the state deems to be high and (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: That the state --
It's an inducement for that end?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, that's true, that's true.
All right (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's an aid to them.

It's an aid, it's an aid to those churches who meet and forward that purpose, whose activity and life in the community forward an interest which the public and the state is interested in which is a benefit to the state and which is a justification for a gratuity, an award which is given to them.
When they fail to meet that purpose, when they fail to accomplish that end, the justification for that reward and gratuity is gone and it is justifiable and proper --
That is when they -- when they fail to maintain the state established standards then they lose the privilege, the exemption?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: State established, yes by (Inaudible) vote of the people, it's --
No, but it is a state established standard.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes I think that means that.
Churches must guide themselves if they have the privilege of the exemption?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Is that it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The question of exemption --
I wonder then if that's so, Justice Burton question isn't particularly pertinent?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The question of exemption I take it is a matter for determination of the state by its people and the question was put by one of you gentlemen to Mr. Wirin as to whether the state could withdraw exemption, assuredly it's a matter of state policy.
I should think that the state can promote whatever the purposes of the church are by giving it a natural benefit, that isn't (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes the exemption of churches from exemption is historical, it's traditional.
I don't think there's any possibility now of questioning it on the basis of idea that it may breach the wall between the church and the state.

How do you, how do you escape that (Inaudible) if it's true as perceived from your statement is -- purpose of the state is to induce by attempting and (Inaudible) churches observe standards of (Inaudible) in connection with the efficacy of doctrine.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Now your question Your Honor?
Question was, how do you -- how can it be said that there is not a (Inaudible) church's doctrine if this is done for the avowed purpose of requiring (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: It's --
-- or requiring to maintain high standards of doctrine.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: It's --
In the judgment of the legislature.
